div1.p: Your card & note should have been mailed last week — sorry.

Thursday night in a down town store at a $1.00 bargain glove counter, & during a real Christmas rush something happened to my billfold. I was thankful Bobby was with me because the loss was worse than it sounds . . . all my identification papers — even my Indentification Card #18314 Student No. as a student at M.U. my picture, my grand daughter's & children's pictures, my Mo. Driver's license etc ----- you have to have lived thruthrough the trouble we have & be strangers in a strange state . . .
div1.note: FAVORABLE: - Note: Kept several appointments at Brown — your letter — Dr. Dealis is already here (& ANOTHER ONE, I heard about — is all I need as a recommendation — Better job offer, too.
div1.p: I do not have to turn in any mss. As far as they can tell me my and have told me my earlier academic record is good enough for me to stop worrying.

Do you think you could write that you knew me well enough to believe I could do the MA in English at Brown? My job which supports children mother + me hinges on some Graduate Education that I lost where "CRM's created situations" forced me to sign out or be signed out. Please & thank you!!
Dean of Graduate School Brown University Providence 12, Rhode Island
div1.note:
Note: -
My Mother is very brave & very courageous — Cliff has either gotten control of or has so acted these 20 years since I married him that all my parents life savings as exhausted. Sad.

opener.dateline: 345 Hope St. Providence 6, Rhode Island Dec. 10, 1957

div1.p: Way past time to write that I love you! I'm sorry I didn't get to see you again. I'm sorry I didn't get to tell you good bye. Happened to see Hilda downtown — I'm sure she wondered what-ever was the matter with me.

I was broken hearted when she saw me. because I knew that Mother Linda & Bobby & I had to go with nothing sellted about C_'s control over my Mother's funds; the divorce in court & ignored ETC — ETC — AD INFINITUM.

We are fortunate to have had the home of one of my parent's old friends (friends for over 35 years) offered us for sanctuary. Just as no one believed he Cliff could have mistreated & hurt us in Columbia as
48
he did, so no one believes he can do it here. However, he is a very determined, clever & ruthless person for all his smooth & charming ways, especially with women.

The children, Linda & Bobby, are happier wothout him in the same town, but they, like me, miss Columbia which had been the only home we knew. Then we lived "close at home" in ways no on knew or realized. Today, for example, was a day of rain, when I missed my "woods" & the chance to stand on the steps Daddy made & look over all the plants & trees.

There are no flowers for me here — but there are three florists shops I can walk by! One of the shops is almost full of poinsettas the down town stores are decorated. Providence is truly an interesting city.

In the true sense we are exiles. Mrs. Neihardt, guess what keepsake I brought with me & have in my top dresser drawer! I have my "Mona NeihartNeihardt piece — my cherub!" Also, I have the note Dr. N. wrote me in Jan. & the "blue" card with his Christmas poem on it. . .

I have been teaching half days in a fine school. At the time I took the half day job I still expected things to be cleared up so I could go ahead & work on the M.A. — & then the Ph.D! Now, I don't know what to do, because I do not have anyone to advise me or at least give their opinion. That was one of the most wonderful experiences of my life to have had the advice to "listen to you"
50
as you know I loved the opportunity of being the student & the opportunity thus provided to listen to your lectures. It was sheet heaven, to have been grader for you for as long as I was permitted to go to school. I miss Dr. Craig's lectures & Dr. Moffett's — the world was better where I knew I could go to class & hear the three of you. I remember all I can of you.

It was a grave disappointment not to have at least spoken to Dr. Moffett just one more time. Dr. Craig spoke to me on Broadway once. It was September of this year. Of course, I do not know that he remembered who I was, but I was happy he spoke.

Back to Graduate School — until I got so tired & discouraged I felt pretty sure of being admitted to Brown University. I can walk to the school where I teach from here & I can walk to Brown & that saves bus fare. Are you still
51
willing to write one more letter recommending me for graduate study. I told both Dr. Anderson (English Dept.) & Dr. Case & Dr. Smith (Education Dept.) that two people were back of me you in English & Earl (W.E. DRAKE) in Education. I said no more than that except for this one remark: I did say the first time I saw Dr. Anderson, English, that I knew I seemed pretty old to try to get two degrees in order to teach but that last year "Dr. Craig said I wasn't" I have purposely not mentioned any names here. I have purposely kept everything
52
on a business basis & for an interview or appointment of only a few minutes. How long it will take for a "whispering campaign" like Cliff used in Columbia. I know not.

Would you think I should send in to Brown with application some of my manuscripts of my poems or would you think it best not to? The application form for admission asked about printed published & mss. work. I salvaged some of it . . . . but very little of 50 years work.
If you are willing to write the letter should go to Dean of the Graduate School, Brown University, Providence 12, Rhode Island.
If you sense discouragement it is real but I hope to rise out of it. God Bless & keep you — each one of you — your pets & horses, too.
